messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:29): Hm, I should make the RDF conversion algorithm ignore itemprop=""s that have no ":" or "." if the item="" was empty
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:44): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: got a second to talk about ARIA?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:45): sure
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:45): we just passed r3600
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:45): if we rotated one degree for each revision, we'd be very dizzy by now, but facing the same way as we started.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:46): little known useless facts, brought to you by Ian.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:46): I think it's not that little known :P
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:46): well if i hadn't told you we'd reached r3600 first :-P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:47): If you'd worked faster and done one commit per second, it would only have taken an hour to reach this far instead of five years
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:47): Now that's a useful fact
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:47): lol
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:47): actually the repo started in like 2006 or 2007 or something
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:48): So like 4 edits per day
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:48): sounds about right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:49): wonders where 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c went
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:50): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: got interrupted, hang on a sec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:50): i have a hard out in 15 minutes

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:50): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Sam convinced one of the PFWG big shots to attend tomorrow's telecon and possibly talk about the blocking last call issues on ARIA
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I'm not even going to ask you to attend, but I plan to
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I'd like to understand your Last Call comments and other objections clearly, so I can give informed comments on their plans
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:52): i'll be asleep and far from any phones at the time of the telecon

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: to be clear - is your concern solely about document conformance, and leaving HTML5 the freedom to define "nonsense" states as nonconforming?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:53): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: i think you understand them -- we just want to be able to have well-defined conformance criteria for authors that are sane (no radiobutton checkboxes or headers that aren't headers or whatnot), and well defined conformance criteria for implementations when the author ones are ignored.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:54): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: let me ask you about one hypothetical
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:55): let's say it is defined that in the <input type="radiobutton" role="checkbox" checked aria-checked="false"> case....

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:56): conformance checkers were allowed to flag the checked/aria-checked conflict as nonconforming, and specs were allowed to specifically define cases as nonconforming, and "native" state is defined to take precedence for implementations

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:56): would it be important to have the same for role, so that for example <input type="radiobutton" role="checkbox" checked> can be disallowed by the host language?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:56): I think your answer will be that, yes, conflicting roles should be disallowed even if no other state is conflicting
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:56): i think that's important, yes
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:56): but I want to confirm
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:57): i'd like to make any contradictions between html semantics and aria semantics a conformance error
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:57): all right, I think I can give them an informed opinion tomorrow, in that case

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:57): and i'd like to make any such contradictions have crystal clear implementation requirements, ideally requirements that cause the visual semantics to be propagated to the AT even if the aria semantics would contradict the visual semantics
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:58): i.e. native semantics should win (i think that would lead to more accessible pages)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:58): roger that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:58): e.g. <h1 role=checkbox> shouldn't be valid either, and should act like an <h1> to ATs, not a checkbox
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:58): I'm assuming that <div>, for example, would have null intrinsic semantics and thus be compatible with any ARIA role
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:58): right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:58): seems likely
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:58): i haven't checked all the roles, but i assume that would be true
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:59): I can also imagine some elements might be compatible with other roles despite having a default one, though I have not checked the list in detail either
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:01): for example, they have an example of giving <li> a menuitem role, which seems reasonable since lists are often used as menus (whether pop-up or static)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:01): seems reasonable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:02): ok i gotta go
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:02): bbl
